abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Previous research focusing on pelagic gastropods in the open ocean has demonstrated that many morphospecies comprise multiple distinct clades or cryptic species that can be distinguished with DNA sequence data. To date, the genetic diversity of the pelagic gastropod fauna of the tropical East Pacific, especially in shallow coastal waters, remains largely unexplored. To document the diversity of pterotracheoids (formerly heteropods) from the coastal waters of the Bay of Panama, we collected, photographed and sequenced fragments of mitochondrial <jats:italic>cytochrome c oxidase subunit I</jats:italic> (<jats:italic>COI</jats:italic>) and <jats:italic>16S</jats:italic> ribosomal DNA for 60 atlantids, 3 carinariids and 6 pterotracheids. In addition to the <jats:italic>COI</jats:italic> barcode, our results include the first published <jats:italic>16S</jats:italic> sequences for these groups. We found 11 operational taxonomic units (OTUs): 9 in the genus <jats:italic>Atlanta</jats:italic>, 1 <jats:italic>Carinaria</jats:italic> and 1 <jats:italic>Firoloida</jats:italic>. We report the presence of <jats:italic>Atlanta oligogyra</jats:italic> (Clades A and B), <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>Atlanta turriculata</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>Atlanta lesueurii</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>Atlanta helicinoidea</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> (Clade B), <jats:italic>Atlanta plana</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>Atlanta echinogyra</jats:italic>, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>Atlanta inflata</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> and <jats:italic>Atlanta frontieri</jats:italic> through comparisons of our sequences with previously published sequences. We did not find <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>Atlanta gaudichaudi</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>Atlanta inclinata</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>, <jats:italic>Atlanta tokiokai</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>Atlanta gibbosa</jats:italic>, <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>Atlanta peronii</jats:italic></jats:styled-content>, or <jats:italic>Oxygyrus inflatus</jats:italic>, which have previously been reported from the region. Haplotype networks and estimates of Φ<jats:sub>ST</jats:sub> illustrate how some species show population differentiation across the tropical Indo‐Pacific region, whereas others show little apparent population structure. For example, the most common haplotypes of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>inflata</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> and of <jats:styled-content style="fixed-case"><jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>turriculata</jats:italic></jats:styled-content> occur in the Indian Ocean, the Central and West Pacific and the tropical East Pacific, whereas individuals of <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>frontieri</jats:italic> from the Indian Ocean do not share haplotypes with individuals of <jats:italic>A</jats:italic>. <jats:italic>frontieri</jats:italic> from the Pacific Ocean. Analyses were limited by sample sizes, but these data suggest that population genetics approaches may be useful for reconstructing population histories of these important, but overlooked, components of the plankton.</jats:p>
title: Diversity and genetic connectivity of heteropod (Pterotracheoidea) gastropods in the Tropical Eastern Pacific
